Comment: This game is more or less focuses on the d7 square, and a pin on Black's knight on that square which I held since move 9. If I had dedicated myself more to the attack on the square on d7, I may have had a pretty strong attack...
King's pawn opening - I deviate from my normal pattern of the English Opening (I wanted a solid position given the rating difference of me and david1223
a symmetrical position so far
a symmetrical position so far
bringing out knight #2 and threatening the d5 square

I remember another annotated game where a knight sacrifice on taking that e6 pawn led to White decimating Black (but that was with the Queen's pawn opening... I may be wrong on this, but I can't remember what the game was, it was awhile ago)
I like to play moves like this when I am in doubt of what else to do
brings out the other knight, and that knight stays there for the rest of the game

Black takes advantage of this move later in the game, but for now this seems like a good move - it opens up castling opportunities and allows a rook-and-queen formation on the d-file when I do castle (I considered Qd3 but felt that Qd2 was safer)
challenging the center - if I retake White's center control is weakened considerably
this is where I see a chance to pin the knight at d7, and focus on that, but after that I pretty much forget the idea of castling
keeping the pressure on that knight
keeping the pressure on that knight
pawn trade
pawn trade
I was expecting g5 here... I should have taken that knight straight away, but I don't realise the significance of this move until it was too late
the pin I mentioned at the beginning
chasing my bishop...
retreating my bishop..
I was expecting this, and then I saw a possible move that could give me the advantage. Was I right?

? No, I wasn't - this move drops me down a piece due to the position of my queen - any other situation and this move would have been great. I saw this as a gambit that was beneficial for White - for the sake of just one point, White could maintain the pin on the h7 knight and create passed pawns on my a and b file (of course, White could simply break the pin by castling, but then I'd just opt for the exchange - the less pieces stopping my pawns, the better)
(!) ouch! This move guarantees Black a piece advantage
(!) ouch! This move guarantees Black a piece advantage
(!) ouch! This move guarantees Black a piece advantage
maybe Bxe7 would have been better - Black would still be a piece up, but it'd clear the queenside up more for my pawns
